newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Amcol bondholders may have long wait.
newsitem.headline: Amcol bondholders may have long wait.

text.p: Amcol Holdings bondholders may not receive payments for at least a year after the listing of a new company taking over the troubled property and trading group, a source close to the bondholders said on Thursday.
Price Waterhouse, the judicial managers of Amcol, last year selected Indonesia's Sinar Mas group to rescue Amcol through an injection of at least US$2.0 billion of assets.
A new company named Golden Amcol, also referred to as Newco, would be formed under a share exchange. Golden Amcol would also seek a listing on the Stock Exchange of Singapore.

The source, close to the holders of Singapore $285 million of Amcol bonds, told Reuters Sinar Mas has proposed "an extension of time of not less than 12 months from the date on which Newco shares are listed" for the repayment on the principle amount of bonds.
According to the source, Sinar Mas has the option to repay bondholders earlier than the stipulated time.
Bondholders would have to waive penalty interest rates for late payment, he said.
Holders of two bonds worth S$170 million, secured against Amcol's property Orchard Towers, would be paid earlier if the property was sold, the source said.
Amcol's bondholders had been fighting for a guarantee from Sinar Mas. Their petition to block appointment of the judicial managers was rejected by the High Court in August.

On Wednesday, the custodian of the bonds, HSBC Trustees, informed holders of Amcol's three sets of bonds -- expiring in 1997, 1998 and 1999 respectively -- through newspaper advertisements that they could obtain a paper explaining the Sinar Mas proposal.
A meeting will be held on March 10 to seek preliminary views of bondholders, the advertisements said.
Another meeting, to seek approval from the bondholders, would be held on April 1, the source said.
According to the daily Straits Times (ST) newspaper on Thursday, trade creditors of an Amcol subsidiary have been given interim payments.
The creditor banks of Amcol unit Sankei have been receiving 35 cents for every dollar of the S$140 million they are owed, subject to certain conditions, banking sources told ST.
Sankei's creditors have been paid out of surplus cash from sale of stocks belonging to the trading subsidiary, the ST said.
Amcol's judicial managers and lawyers were not immediately available for comment.
